f5c95cc981bd.name: Startup Grind
f5c95cc981bd.description: The life, work, and tactics of entrepreneurs around the world — by founders, for founders. Welcoming submissions on technology trends, product design, growth strategies, and venture investing.
f5c95cc981bd.shortDescription: The life, work, and tactics of entrepreneurs around the…

paragraphs.name: 9c2c
paragraphs.text: Of all of the books on this list, The Writer’s Journey might be my favorite. It’s taught me more about story structure than any other resource, including my undergraduate and graduate work in creative writing. It’s a step-by-step guide through the classic hero’s journey with examples and exercises that will improve your writing if you pay attention. My free course The Plotting Workshop is based on The Writer’s Journey.

paragraphs.name: 037c
paragraphs.text: “Writing isn’t about making money, getting famous, getting dates, getting laid, or making friends. In the end, it’s about enriching the lives of those who will read your work, and enriching your own life, as well. It’s about getting up, getting well, and getting over. Getting happy, okay? Getting happy.”

paragraphs.name: e0a3
paragraphs.text: Self-Editing for Fiction Writers by Renni Browne and Dave King

paragraphs.name: ca6d
paragraphs.text: Actually, what I need is help getting my stuff published once it’s written.

paragraphs.name: 5ae4
paragraphs.text: According to the intro to this book, Steering the Craft started as a course Ursula K. Le Guin gave to aspiring writers. I can’t tell you how badly I wish I’d been able to take that class! She teaches writers not only how to write, but how to make the story become a living thing for the reader. Beautiful.

paragraphs.text: If you don’t have time for a book, Ann Patchett’s essay, “The Getaway Car: A Practical Memoir About Writing and Life” does it for me every single time.

b6d3bc175300.title: You have Stephen King, but you missed several similar books by other extremely successful writers.

paragraphs.name: 01a0
paragraphs.text: You have Stephen King, but you missed several similar books by other extremely successful writers. For instance Lawrence Block has several books on writing that are in King’s class. His “Write for Your Life”, “Telling Lies for Fun & Profit” and “Spider, Spin me a Web” are well worth a look.

paragraphs.text: Looks like a very useful list, thanks. I’ve already read On Writing by Stephen King, which is outstanding. Write. Publish. Repeat is very helpful as well.

paragraphs.text: I love your suggestions. I have one more. It’s certainly more for the nonfiction and business writers, but I coach a lot of them, so it helps me help them.

a9691d834540.title: I would add “Ernest Hemingway on Writing” — if you think writing is difficult for you, wait until…

paragraphs.name: 9a95
paragraphs.text: I would add “Ernest Hemingway on Writing” — if you think writing is difficult for you, wait until you learn how difficult it was for him, then feel better.

paragraphs.text: I’ve read a few of the books on this list. But no writing book holds a candle to The Art of Dramatic Writing by Lagros Egri. It was written in the 40's.

paragraphs.name: 68db
paragraphs.text: The language used in the Table of Contents sounds close to (or like a modern version of) Joseph Campbell’s The Hero With a Thousand Faces. How heavily does Christopher Vogler draw on Campbell, and how much new material does he contribute?

paragraphs.name: 1d2f
paragraphs.text: Well…there are two books on the list that will help with that. True story, though, if you’re not writing well, it’s much harder to get published. It happens, but it’s way harder.

paragraphs.text: Great suggestions! Thanks for this.

paragraphs.text: BIRD BY BIRD, by Anne Lamott!

paragraphs.name: 5aa5
paragraphs.text: Shaunta, a great list. Of them, the one I recommend most is The Writer’s Journey, especially since most of my clients are mystery or SF/F writers and that book nails it for them. One you missed is the 1934 classic Becoming a Writer by Dorthea Brande. It is about the mindset of writers — something that is a timeless subject (and issue!). Sometimes a…

paragraphs.name: c0f6
paragraphs.text: Interesting list. Good stuff to look up next time I visit one of the local chain or independent bookstores for used or new. We have several good ones in the area in the PNW: Village Bookstore in Bellingham, Barnes and Noble — several Seattle area locations, Twice Used Books in Seattle, Elliott Bay Bookstore in Seattle, Third Place Books (new and used…
